_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

This Executive Summary briefly describes the major elements of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for Highwater Ethanol, LLC (Highwater Ethanol).  This summary is presented in response to the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR 68) and Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act.  The Highwater Ethanol facility is subject to the RMP rule due to the storage of natural gasoline denaturant (a flammable mixture), which contains n-pentane, isopentane, neopentane, and butane, which are regulated substances above the threshold quantities.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:

Highwater Ethanol is committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment from any hazardous substances used in its chemical manufacturing process, specifically natural gasoline.  It is the policy of Highwater Ethanol to comply with all Federal, State and Local laws. The Highwater Ethanol facility has a detailed Emergency Response Plan that is utilized to respond to any accidental releases. 

Highwater Ethanol has emergency response policies in place that are addressed in the facility's Health and Safety Plan, Industrial Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP), Spill Prevention, Controls, and Countermeasures Plan (SPCC), Facility Response Plan (FRP), and Emergency Action Plan. Most of the listed Plans have annual training requirements (at a minimum) to keep employees educated on emergency response procedures in place at the facility.  All new employees are required to attend orientation where the Plans listed above are reviewed.  New employees also undergo training on emergency response procedures prior to initiating responsibilities onsite.



Highwater Ethanol's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond

defensively to contain the release as necessary.



DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:

Highwater Ethanol is located in Lamberton, Redwood County, Minnesota.  The facility operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for the purpose of manufacturing fuel grade ethanol from the natural fermentation of corn.  The facility stores natural gasoline (regulated flammable mixture), which is used as a denaturant in the ethanol fuel product.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

Highwater Ethanol is committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment from any hazardous substances used in its chemical manufacturing process, specifically natural gasoline.  It is the policy of Highwater Ethanol to comply with all Federal, State and Local laws. Highwater Ethanol's maintenance staff performs regular preventative maintenance inspections, as required by the manufacturer's recommendations and/or State and Federal regulations.  Monthly and quarterly visual inspections are performed and documented.  Quarterly Leak Detection and Repair (LDAR) monitoring is performed and reports filed per State and Federal regulations.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

The facility has not had any accidents reportable under RMP within the past five years.  



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

Highwater Ethanol has several safety programs in place at the facility that incorporate emergency response, including the Health and Safety Plan and Facility Response Plan.  Highwater Ethanol also maintains an Emergency Action Plan that details evacuation and response procedures for spills, releases, and fire, etc.  The plans listed in this section have been prepared in accordance with applicable regulations.  Training is conducted in accordance with these plans and applicable requirements. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

Highwater Ethanol provides safety training to its employees on an annual bas
is.  Contractors are trained on plant-specific safety procedures prior to initiating work onsite.  Any changes to improve safety will be implemented immediately upon discovery of needed changes.
